Article Title: This may be the '$12 billion proof' that all is not well between Microsoft and ChatGPT maker OpenAI
Article Text:
Adds another crease in Microsoft-OpenAI relationship

CoreWeave’s Rise: From Crypto to AI Powerhouse

In a blockbuster move shaking up the AI infrastructure landscape, OpenAI has signed a five-year, $11.9 billion agreement with CoreWeave, a GPU-heavy cloud service provider, as first reported by Reuters and confirmed by CoreWeave in a press release. The deal, which includes OpenAI acquiring $350 million in CoreWeave equity, marks a significant win for both companies and underscores shifting alliances in the race for AI dominance. What makes the deal interesting is that is that before this deal, CoreWeave’s biggest customer is reported to be Microsoft. According to TechCrunch, in 2024, Microsoft accounted for 62% of CoreWeave’s revenue, which grew to a stunning $1.9 billion — nearly an eight-fold increase from just $228.9 million in 2023.CoreWeave, a company backed by Nvidia (which holds a 6% stake), operates an AI-specific cloud service powered by a network of 32 data centers. As of late 2024, it boasted over 250,000 Nvidia GPUs, with recent additions including Nvidia’s cutting-edge Blackwell GPUs designed for AI reasoning. The company, which filed to go public last week but has yet to set a debut date or pricing, saw its revenue skyrocket to $1.9 billion in 2024—up nearly eightfold from $228.9 million in 2023. Until now, Microsoft accounted for a hefty 62% of that revenue, making OpenAI’s entry as a major customer a game-changer.The agreement comes as CoreWeave prepares for a planned IPO aiming to raise $4 billion or more. Heavy reliance on Microsoft had raised concerns among potential investors, but securing OpenAI in a multi-billion-dollar deal could smooth the path forward, easing worries about customer concentration.The deal adds a new twist to the increasingly strained relationship between OpenAI and Microsoft, its longtime backer. Microsoft, which has a profit-sharing arrangement with OpenAI, was once its sole cloud provider. But tensions have simmered as OpenAI’s ambitions have grown, pitting the two against each other in the enterprise AI market. OpenAI is reportedly developing expensive AI agents, while Microsoft is building its own “reasoning” models, including the MAI family, to rival OpenAI’s o1 and o3-mini offerings. Microsoft even tapped Mustafa Suleyman, a rival to OpenAI CEO Sam Altman , to lead its AI division.This isn’t the first sign of OpenAI diversifying its infrastructure. In January, as part of the massive Stargate AI project with SoftBank, Oracle, and others, OpenAI ended Microsoft’s exclusivity as its cloud provider. Altman has been vocal about the company’s need for more computing power, recently lamenting that OpenAI is “out of GPUs.” Now, with direct access to CoreWeave’s resources—and an ownership stake in the company—OpenAI is flexing its independence.CoreWeave’s journey to this point is as unconventional as it is impressive. Founded by former hedge fund executives, the company began as a crypto mining operation before pivoting to AI cloud services . Its three co-founders have already cashed out $488 million in shares—over $150 million each—while CoreWeave carries a hefty $7.9 billion in debt.
Article Summary: OpenAI has signed a five-year, $11.9 billion agreement with CoreWeave, a GPU- heavy cloud service provider. The deal includes OpenAI acquiring $350 million inCoreWeave equity. In 2024, Microsoft accounted for 62% of Core weave’s revenue, which grew to a stunning $1.9billion.

Article Title: Why Expedia Group, Airbnb and other travel stocks are seeing one of the biggest-ever fall
Article Text:
Travel follows Tech's Magnificent Seven

Tourism-related stocks took a significant hit on Tuesday, March 11, after several major US airlines issued warnings about declining travel demand, sparking concerns over the health of the broader American economy. Shares of Expedia Group (EXPE) were among the hardest hit, plummeting about 8% and making the travel giant one of the biggest decliners in the S&P 500. Airbnb stock too faced a rout.The selloff followed cautious outlooks from Delta Air Lines (DAL), American Airlines (AAL), and Southwest Airlines (LUV), all of which lowered their forecasts for key first-quarter 2025 metrics, including revenue, earnings per share (EPS), and available seat miles. Airline executives attributed the downward revisions to an uncertain macroeconomic environment and disruptions caused by severe weather events, such as the California wildfires in January.Despite the gloomy industry outlook, Southwest Airlines shares managed to buck the trend, climbing higher after the company announced new revenue-generating initiatives like the introduction of baggage fees. The ripple effect of the airlines’ warnings was felt across the travel sector. Booking Holdings (BKNG) and major hotel chains including Hyatt Hotels (H), Hilton Worldwide Holdings (HLT), and Marriott International (MAR) all saw their shares slide on Tuesday. Cruise line stocks also suffered, with Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings (NCLH), Carnival Corp. (CCL), and Viking Holdings (VIK) registering declines.The huge dip in travel stocks comes just a day after billions were wiped out from the market cap of America's biggest technology stocks. Apple, Microsoft, Tesla, Nvidia, Google-parent Alphabet, Amazon and Meta make America's Magnificent Seven. These seven biggest American technology companies are known for their market dominance. In stock market carnage just a day earlier (March 10), these seven most valuable tech companies lost more than $750 billion in market value.
Article Summary: Shares of Expedia Group (EXPE) were among the hardest hit, plummeting about 8% and making the travel giant one of the biggest decliners in the S&P 500. Delta Air Lines, American Airlines, and Southwest Airlines all lowered their forecasts for key first-quarter 2025 metrics.

Article Title: Amazon cloud’s top AI executive is leaving one year after joining the company
Article Text:
How AWS leadership has changed after reorganisation

Amazon Web Services ' vice president of AI/ML services , Baskar Sridharan , is leaving the company just one year after joining, a report has said. His departure follows a significant reorganisation within AWS's artificial intelligence division.Citing people familiar with the matter, Business Insider reported that Swami Sivasubramanian, vice president of AI and data, has been promoted to lead this new division and will now report directly to AWS CEO Matt Garman. Sridharan had previously reported to Sivasubramanian.Sridharan, who previously worked at Google Cloud and Microsoft for over 20 years, was responsible for overseeing AWS's flagship AI products, including Bedrock and SageMaker.Bedrock has been AWS's primary offering in the competitive AI market, providing developers access to multiple AI models through a single platform.The leadership change comes amid a major restructuring that established a new Agentic AI team within AWS.As part of the reorganisation, the Bedrock and SageMaker AI organisations will move under AWS's compute team led by VP Dave Brown. Prasad Kalyanaraman, VP of AWS infrastructure services, will assume responsibility for several networking teams and VP of technology Mai-Lan Tomsen Bukovec will incorporate additional data service units.Meanwhile, Amazon's Q chatbot teams will be integrated into the new Agentic AI groupSridharan joins several other high-profile executives who have recently left AWS, including former CEO Adam Selipsky, CMO Raejeanne Skillern, CFO Richard Puccio, and AI VP Matt Wood.In an internal email, Garman highlighted the strategic importance of the reorganization, noting that the new Agentic AI team has the potential to build Amazon's “next multi-billion-dollar business” as the company competes with Google, OpenAI, and others in the rapidly evolving AI market.“We're in the midst of the most significant technological transformation since the inception of cloud computing, and our customers are seeing unprecedented productivity gains through generative AI,” Garman wrote.
Article Summary: Baskar Sridharan was responsible for overseeing AWS's flagship AI products, including Bedrock and SageMaker. Swami Sivasubramanian, vice president of AI and data, has been promoted to lead this new division.

Article Title: How Jim Walker, the man who saw 2008 Stock Market crash coming, may have just 'agreed' with Zerodha CEO Nithin Kamath's 'Stock Market Gyaan'
Article Text:
Jim Walker to investors: Take long-term investment approach

Jim Walker picks India over China

Indian stock markets witnessed Bears onslaught in the month of February, with the benchmark Sensex closing over 4,000 points lower. The carnage witnessed in the market during the month led to a staggering erosion of over Rs 40 lakh crore from the market capitalisation of BSE-listed companies; while Nifty 50 marked its longest losing streak since its inception in the year 1996. The relentless downward trend has left retail investors anxious. In a message to investors late earlier this week, Zerodha founder and CEO Nithin Kamath termed the fall as "the first real market correction " since Covid pandemic."Markets are cyclical, and given the way our markets went up from late 2020, this fall was inevitable," he said. Kamath told investors to not get carried away by the doom and gloom in the market and continue investing in SIPs. "I don't know how good the data is, but it seems like the number of investors stopping their SIPs has gone up. This is the wrong thing to do. What an SIP helps you do is to average your investments across different market cycles," he said.A similar sentiment comes from Jim Walker, a celebrated economist from Alethia Capital who famously foresaw the 2008 financial crisis. In an exclusive interaction with ETNow, Walker gave perspective on the current state of the global economy and what he thinks about India. Contrary to widespread concerns that today’s market exuberance might precipitate a collapse akin to that of 2008, Walker holds a different view.Speaking with ETNow, he acknowledged a global economic slowdown but stressed that the circumstances differ markedly from those preceding the financial debacle over ten years ago. Similar to Nithin Kamath, Walker batted for a long-term investment approach. Walker encouraged his clients to boost their stakes in India, despite valuation concerns in its stock market. “I’ve advised clients this week to significantly increase their investments in India. Though stock valuations raise eyebrows, I believe economic growth will soon justify them with strong corporate earnings,” he elaborated.Known for his prescient 2006-07 warning of a looming U.S. housing market crash, Walker remarked that today’s danger signals are less evident. “The signs were glaring in 2006-07 when we predicted a severe downturn driven by excesses in the property sector; it’s not the same now,” he said.He pointed out that unlike the lead-up to 2008, there are currently no significant overindulgences in the housing or financial sectors poised to spark a major banking crisis. Although certain areas show excessive stock market gains and asset price inflation, Walker believes these won’t lead to widespread corporate failures that could rattle the banking system. “We’re not seeing the kind of corporate collapses that impacted banks in 2008. That’s not on the horizon,” he observed.Additionally, Walker expressed a stronger preference for investing in India over China, suggesting it might be an opportune moment to increase investments there. He is especially sanguine about India’s prospects, citing its robust policy environment—the best in three decades—as a key factor enhancing its appeal to investors. “India’s policy stability and certainty are at their peak in the last 30 years,” he asserted, crediting solid monetary and fiscal policies along with exchange rate stability for bolstering India’s economic structure.He also commended the Indian government’s steps toward deregulation and business-friendly policies, seeing them as key drivers of future growth. Walker believes that supporting small and medium enterprises will further boost economic and job expansion.
Article Summary: Jim Walker picks India over China as a good place to invest in the stock market. Walker is known for his prescient warning of a looming U.S. housing market crash in 2006-07. He is sanguine about India’s prospects, citing its robust policy environment as a key factor enhancing its appeal.

Article Title: Income Tax officials may be able to access your email, Facebook, Instagram and other social media accounts starting FY2026-27 if they suspect ...
Article Text:
What is the new addition 'Virtual Digital Space' to the Income Tax Act

Come April 1 of Fiscal Year 2026-27, a new rule in the Income Tax Act law may grant the Income Tax department powers to access your social media accounts or emails in case they suspect tax evasion . Income Tax Bill 2025, which was introduced in the Parliament recently, will give Income Tax officials the legal authourity to access and inspect a wide range of personal and financial digital spaces, termed Virtual Digital Spaces in the bill. This means that the Income Tax department can break into social media accounts, personal emails, bank accounts, online investment accounts, trading accounts, and more if they have any reason to believe that you own any undisclosed income, money, Gold, Jewelry, or valuable item or property on which you haven’t paid applicable Income Tax.Presently, Section 132 of the Income Tax Act, 1961, allows Income Tax officials to seize assets and books during search operations if they find sufficient reasons to believe that an individual is in possession of undisclosed income or assets. The changes in the bill, once passed in the Parliament, will extend this authourity to the digital realm, allowing officials to bypass security measures on computer systems and virtual spaces.The Clause 247 of the Income Tax Bill outlines this expanded power, stating that officers can “break open the lock of any door, box, locker, safe, almirah, or other receptacle” or “gain access by overriding the access code” to computer systems or virtual digital spaces when access is otherwise unavailable. This applies if they believe an individual possesses undisclosed income or assets taxable under the law.According to the bill, the term Virtual Digital Space includes email servers, social media accounts, online investment accounts, trading accounts, banking accounts, and any website used for storing details of ownership of any asset. It further adds that virtual digital space is an environment, area or realm that is constructed and experienced through computer technology and not the physical, tangible world, which encompasses any digital realm that allows users to interact, communicate and perform activities using computer systems, computer networks, computer resources, communication devices, cyberspace, internet, worldwide web and emerging technologies, using data and information in the electronic form for creation, storage or exchange and includes:* Email servers* Social media account* Online investment account, trading account, banking account, etc* Any website used for storing details of ownership of any asset* Remote server or cloud servers* Digital application platforms* Any other space of similar natureAs to who all can wield this authority? The bill designates “authorised officers” as senior tax officials, including Joint Directors, Additional Directors, Joint Commissioners, Additional Commissioners, Assistant or Deputy Directors, Assistant or Deputy Commissioners, Income Tax Officers, and Tax Recovery Officers.What does this mean for individuals? The new rules significantly widen the scope of tax investigations, giving officials the ability to probe deeply into personal and financial digital footprints. As this provision takes effect, it raises questions about privacy and the balance between tax enforcement and individual rights.
Article Summary: Income Tax Bill 2025 will give Income Tax officials the legal authourity to access and inspect a wide range of personal and financial digital spaces. This includes email servers, social media accounts, online investment accounts, trading accounts, banking accounts, and any website used for storing details of ownership of any asset.

Article Title: How this 21-year-old is helping techies ‘crack’ online job interviews
Article Text:
Representative image

A 21-year-old Columbia University student has created a tool that helps software engineers use artificial intelligence to crack virtual technical job interviews. Chungin "Roy" Lee founded Interview Coder , a service that provides real-time AI assistance during coding interviews while remaining undetectable to interviewers."Everyone programs nowadays with the help of AI," said Lee. "It doesn't make sense to have an interview format that assumes you don't have the use of AI."The service, which costs $60 per month, is reportedly on track to hit $1 million in annual recurring revenue by mid-May, according to CNBC.Lee claims he received internship offers from Amazon, Meta, and TikTok after using his own software to cheat during their technical interviews. The companies later rescinded their offers after he posted videos demonstrating how he passed an Amazon interview using AI."I thought I wanted to work at a big tech company and spent 600 hours practicing for Leetcode," Lee told CNBC. "It made me miserable, and I almost stopped programming because of how much I didn't like it."Tech companies are struggling to adapt. Google CEO Sundar Pichai suggested during a February town hall that hiring managers consider returning to in-person interviews to combat AI cheating. Other companies like Deloitte and Anthropic have already made similar changes.Henry Kirk, a software developer who hosted a virtual coding challenge, discovered that more than 50% of applicants were cheating. "The problem is now I don't trust the results as much," Kirk said.Lee's tool is marketed as "invisible to all screen-recording softwares" and aims to disrupt the traditional Leetcode interview process used by major tech companies.When asked if he worries about software engineers losing the trust of the tech industry, Lee responded: "My reaction to that is any company that is slow to respond to market changes will get hurt and that's the fault of the company. If there are better tools, then it's their fault for not resorting to the better alternative to exist. I don't feel guilty at all for not catering to a company's inability to adapt."Columbia University has opened disciplinary proceedings against Lee, according to documents viewed by CNBC.
Article Summary: Chungin "Roy" Lee founded Interview Coder, a service that provides real-time AI assistance during coding interviews while remaining undetectable to interviewers. Lee claims he received internship offers from Amazon, Meta, and TikTok after using his own software to cheat during their technical interviews.

Article Title: Tesla offers deals and discounts as sales hit: Zero percent loans, free lifetime charging and more

These allegations come at a time when Tesla is facing growing criticism from activists and a shift in consumer sentiment, raising questions about the extent of political influence on corporate reputations.In a recent tweet, Musk specifically pointed to five organizations—Troublemakers, Disruption Project, Rise & Resist, Indivisible Project, and the Democratic Socialists of America—as being behind the recent wave of Tesla protests. These groups have been involved in various demonstrations, which Musk claims are not spontaneous but instead part of a broader effort to undermine Tesla.His post encouraged users to provide further information about the alleged connections between these activist groups and their funding sources. The platform, known for fundraising for Democratic candidates and progressive causes, has recently come under scrutiny for allegedly accepting unauthorized foreign donations. These allegations have led to the resignation of several senior officials, adding further complexity to Musk’s accusations.However, no public evidence has surfaced directly linking ActBlue’s financial activities to anti-Tesla demonstrations. Musk’s assertions remain unverified, and none of the groups he mentioned have publicly responded to his claims.

Article Title: How and why Elon Musk's public spat with Poland FM led to almost 400% jump in stock price of Europe's Starlink rival
Article Text:
How Does The Starlink System Work?

Can Eutelsat Take Over From Elon Musk's Starlink



Eutelsat, Europe's rival to Elon Musk's Starlink, has seen its stock soar by nearly 390% last week. Eutelsat is a French company that produces satellites for data connectivity. Speculation about a shifting landscape in European defense and satellite connectivity is reported to be behind the big jump. The company’s share price experienced dramatic swings, surging as much as 77% March 4 and an additional 120% on March 5. From its February 28 closing value to March 7th's close, Eutelsat’s stock climbed an astonishing 387%. The rally has persisted this week, with shares rising more than 20% on March 10.For those unaware, France-based Eutelsat launches satellites into low Earth orbit (LEO) and geostationary orbit (GEO) using rockets from companies like SpaceX, founded by Elon Musk. After merging with British satellite operator OneWeb in 2023, Eutelsat became the world’s third-largest satellite operator by revenue, positioning it as a competitor to SpaceX’s Starlink internet service.The rally in Eutelsat's stock started amid reports that Eutelsat could step in as a replacement for SpaceX's Starlink in Ukraine, where Elon Musk’s service has provided critical internet access to the military during its ongoing dispute with Russia. Recently, US-Ukraine relations soured after a disastrous meeting between Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelensky and the US President Donald Trump. Zelensky left the White House without signing a mineral agreement that was reported to be on the table. The US halted military aid to Ukraine after the public showdown. Some reports also suggested that the US may cut Ukraine’s Starlink access.Eutelsat is reported to be exploring an expanded role in Ukraine with the EU. CEO Eva Berneke told Bloomberg last week, “Everyone is asking us today, ‘Can you replace the large number of terminals in Ukraine,’ and we are looking at that.” With 35 GEO satellites and an LEO network of over 600 satellites, Eutelsat has the capacity to provide significant support.On March 4, Eutelsat revealed it was negotiating with the European Union to bolster internet services in Ukraine. The company’s stock had already started climbing the previous day, fueled by speculation it could fill a Starlink-sized gap if US-Ukraine talks collapse again.The situation grew more complex over the past week when Musk clashed on Twitter with Poland’s Foreign Minister Radoslaw Sikorski. The public spat started after Sikorski claimed that Poland pays for Ukraine to use the services of Starlink. He further went on to claim that Elon Musk is planning to shut down Starlink terminals in Ukraine. This angered both the US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk. The duo sharply responded to Sikorski, dismissing Polish FM's concerns about Starlink being cut off. The US Secretary accused Poland's foreign minister of "making things up". Musk warned that Ukraine’s “entire front line” would collapse without Starlink. In a post on Twitter, Elon Musk said that no matter how much he disagreed on Ukraine policy, Starlink would never turn off its terminals in the country. "Exactly! To be extremely clear, no matter how much I disagree with the Ukraine policy, Starlink will never turn off its terminals. I am simply stating that, without Starlink, the Ukrainian lines would collapse, as the Russians can jam all other communications! We would never do such a thing or use it as a bargaining chip," wrote Elon Musk.Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk later defended his minister, praising his diplomatic approach.
Article Summary: Eutelsat, Europe's rival to Elon Musk's Starlink, has seen its stock soar by nearly 390% last week. Speculation about a shifting landscape in European defense and satellite connectivity is reported to be behind the big jump. The rally has persisted this week, with shares rising more than 20% on March 10.

Article Title: How DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng has given a new tourist destination to Chinese
Article Text:
How DeepSeek founders village is turning into a tourist spot



DeepSeek founder and CEO Liang Wenfeng 's AI success has transformed his Chinese village, Mililing, into a popular tourist destination. Located in southern China, Mililing, once an underdeveloped hamlet, is now experiencing a tourism boom directly linked to the fame of its native son and his AI company, DeepSeek.Local authorities have reportedly responded to this visitor surge by initiating a "facelift" for the village. Before this transformation, Mililing was a quiet village of nearly 700 residents, with younger generations primarily employed in shoe manufacturing and the elderly engaged in agriculture. The village committee's director, Liang Wenfen, confirmed the tourism surge and the subsequent development efforts to a South China Morning Post report.As Liang's achievements gained global recognition, Mililing began attracting visitors driven by admiration and curiosity. According to the committee director, groups of travelers—including families with children and employees in company uniforms—have been visiting the village since January.During the Spring Festival holiday (January 29 to February 10), the village welcomed around 10,000 tourists daily, he added.In response to the sudden influx of visitors and complaints about inadequate infrastructure, local authorities launched a renovation effort. As reported by SCMP, 29 houses had their exterior walls repaired and repainted, while dilapidated structures were demolished.Roads were widened, sewage drains were installed, and streets were cleaned and cleared of weeds. Additionally, trees were planted to enhance the village’s appearance.Some tourists have even taken "souvenirs" from the area. “Some visitors took away piles of soil, stones, or pieces of leaves,” a resident identified only by his surname, Yuan, told the publication.However, the recent developments have placed the DeepSeek founder's grandfather in a difficult position. As the sole occupant of their four-story house in the village, the elderly man keeps his front door shut for most of the day, fearing harassment from the tourists.Liang completed his primary education in this village before enrolling at Wuchuan No 1 Middle School, a key educational institution in the region.In 2002, he secured a high score in the country's university entrance exam, the gaokao, earning him a place at the Zhejiang University.
Article Summary: DeepSeek founder and CEO Liang Wenfeng's AI success has transformed his Chinese village into a popular tourist destination. Mililing, once an underdeveloped hamlet, is now experiencing a tourism boom directly linked to the fame of its native son. Local authorities have reportedly responded to this visitor surge by initiating a "facelift" for the village.

Article Title: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon on return-to-office policy: I completely respect people who don't want to go to office all 5 days a week, but then...
Article Text:
JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon

Dimon blames "people in the middle" for not returning to the office



JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon defended his bank's strict return-to-office mandate while acknowledging employee concerns in recent statements across multiple forums. The banking giant is requiring employees to return to in-person work five days a week starting this March, ending remote work options that remained after pandemic restrictions."I completely respect people that don't want to go to the office all five days a week. That's your right. It's my right. It's a citizen's right," Dimon told CNBC in February. "But they should respect that the company is going to decide what's good for the clients, the company, etc., not an individual."The CEO's comments follow a viral town hall incident where Dimon responded with strong language to an employee's question about flexibility in return-to-office policies, igniting debate within the organization and across the financial industry.Dimon later categorized critics of the policy as "people in the middle," during an appearance at Stanford Graduate School of Business. "If you work in a restaurant, you got to be in. You all may not know this, but 60% of Americans worked the whole time," Dimon said, referencing frontline workers during the pandemic.The policy has sparked concern among JPMorgan's technology workforce , with some employees reportedly considering leaving. With a $17 billion IT budget and nearly 60,000 technology workers, the bank faces potential talent retention challenges as competitors like Citigroup maintain hybrid work options .Despite the pushback, Dimon has remained firm on the policy. "Jamie Dimon's like, 'Well, hey, if you don't like it, you know where the door is.' Yes, we do," one technology vice president told Business Insider, speaking anonymously. "And that's going to impact him. He's going to lose some good people."
Article Summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon defended his bank's strict return-to-office mandate. The banking giant is requiring employees to return to in-person work five days a week starting this March. The policy has sparked concern among JPMorgan's technology workforce.

Article Title: Infosys, KPMG and other technology companies are ramping up hiring for these roles
Article Text: In response to the growing need for AI trust and safety , tech multinationals, consulting firms, global capability centers, and IT services companies are aggressively hiring for specialised roles that focus on the privacy, responsibility, and governance aspects of AI. This surge in hiring comes as companies invest heavily in ensuring that their AI technologies are both safe and ethical.Companies like Infosys, KPMG, and Accenture are leading the charge in ramping up their AI trust and safety teams. According to data from Teamlease Digital, hiring in this space has increased by 36% year-on-year, with demand expected to grow by 25-30% in 2025. Quess IT Staffing also projects a 15-25% rise in hiring for these roles this year and a cumulative growth of 30-40% over the next 1-2 years.The specialised roles in high demand include trust and safety specialists, AI safety data scientists, responsible AI analysts, AI policy advisors, ethical AI researchers, AI ethics specialists, data privacy officers, AI risk analysts, and responsible AI and AI governance managers. These roles are critical in ensuring that AI technologies are developed and deployed responsibly.As reported by Economic Times, Infosys has established a dedicated responsible AI office to spearhead auditing, governance practices, and advanced monitoring mechanisms for AI technology. Balakrishna DR, executive vice-president, global services head, AI and industry verticals at Infosys, stated, "With the rapid acceleration of AI adoption and evolving regulatory landscapes, the importance of specialized roles in AI responsibility has never been greater. Over the past two years, we have significantly expanded our team and continue to invest in hiring specialists."KPMG is also expanding its responsible AI team in India, seeking multidisciplinary thinkers who can navigate AI complexities beyond traditional software development. Akhilesh Tuteja, partner at KPMG India, emphasised the need for specialists in AI governance & risk management, ethical AI & policy development, and AI security & privacy.Accenture's chief responsible AI officer, Arnab Chakraborty, highlighted the importance of having the right talent to establish AI governance principles, conduct AI risk assessments, and ensure ongoing monitoring and compliance. "Responsible AI creates the trust that drives adoption of AI at scale, leading to greater innovation and value," Chakraborty said.Beyond the tech sector, industries such as BFSI, healthcare, telecom, and retail are also ramping up demand for AI trust and safety roles. Kapil Joshi, CEO of Quess IT Staffing, noted that focus on compliance and risk management is driving this demand. In BFSI alone, a 25-30% rise in demand is expected due to concerns around data privacy and algorithmic bias.Despite the growing demand, India's AI trust and safety talent pool is still expanding, with 79% of employers struggling to find the right talent. Krishna Vij, VP of TeamLease Digital, emphasised the need for specialised education and training programs to address the gap. Companies are partnering with universities to create AI governance programs and upskilling initiatives.
Article Summary: Hiring in this space has increased by 36% year-on-year, with demand expected to grow by 25-30% in 2025. Infosys has established a dedicated responsible AI office to spearhead auditing, governance practices, and advanced monitoring mechanisms.
